conclusion: Analyze the p-V diagram to determine the work done by the gas from state B to state C.
The image is a p-V diagram showing the process of an ideal gas from state A to state B and then to state C, with pressure on the vertical axis and volume on the horizontal axis.
The temperature in state A is given as 27°C.
The p-V diagram shows the gas undergoing a process from state A to state B and then to state C.
The temperature in state A is 27°C, which is isothermal. Therefore, the work done in this process is zero.
The question asks for the work done from state B to state C.
From state B to state C, the gas expands isothermally at the temperature of state A.
The work done by an ideal gas in an isothermal expansion is given by the formula: W = nRT ln(V2/V1).
Since the temperature is constant, the work done is proportional to the natural logarithm of the ratio of the final volume to the initial volume.
The diagram shows that the gas expands from state B to state C, meaning V2 > V1.
Therefore, the work done by the gas from state B to state C is positive.
The exact value of work done depends on the specific volumes and the gas constant, but the diagram indicates an increase in volume, thus indicating positive work.
